container-title: On the Neanderthals, see Dimitra Papaianni and ­Michael A. Morse, The Neanderthals Rediscovered: How Modern Science Is Rewriting Their Story
title: On ancient DNA, see David Reich Who We Are and How We Got Here
Richard W. Wrangham, Catching Fire: How ­Cooking Made Us Human
covers this important development

note: For a richly ­illustrated, picture-led, book profiling over 20 ancient hominin species, see Alice Roberts Evolution
title: On modern human origins, see: Chris Stringer, Lone Survivors: How We Came to Be the Only Humans on Earth
African Exodus: The ­Origins of Modern Humanity

container-title: Andrew Moore’s Village on the Euphrates
The Oxford Illustrated Prehistory of Europe
Charles Higham’s The Archaeology of Mainland Southeast Asia
Antiquity
note: is comprehensive and authoritative, while his article coauthored with Tracey L.
is a good source for early rice agriculture. For the Americas, see Bruce Smith, The Emergence of Agriculture, already cited.
title: describes the Abu Hureyra excavations and is the finest and most comprehensive monograph on an ancient farming settlement ever written. Ian Hodder, The Leopard’s Tale
is a fascinating analysis of the beliefs behind the early farming settlement at Çatalhöyük, Turkey
The Origins of Agriculture in Europe
For early farming in Asia, see Li Liu, The Chinese Neolithic
The Archaeology of China: From the Late Palaeolithic to the Early Bronze Age
is also valuable
The Origins and Dispersal of Rice Cultivation

container-title: Kirch’s The Evolution of the Polynesian Chiefdoms
Medieval Mississippians: The Cahokian World
­Beyond Chiefdoms: Pathways to Complexity in Africa

editor.literal: and also Timothy R. Pauketat and ­Susan M. Alt, eds.

title: On the Road of the Winds: An Archaeological History of the ­Pacific Islands before European Contact
summarizes the first colonization of the Pacific Islands
describes complex societies in the Pacific. For New Zealand archaeology, see Janet Davidson, The Prehistory of New Zealand
Southwestern archaeology is well analyzed by Linda Cordell, and Maxine McBrinn, The Prehistory of the Southwest
For the eastern woodlands
The Moundbuilders
contains a collection of essays essential to anyone interested in the archaeology of chiefdoms

container-title: Fargher, How ­Humans Cooperate: Confronting the Challenges of Collective Action
note: Justin Jennings, Killing Civilization: A Reassessment of Early Urbanism and Its Consequences ­(Albuquerque: University of New Mexico Press, 2016), and Norman Yoffee, Myths of the Archaic State: Evolution of the Earliest Cities, States,
title: The Rise of Civilization: From Early Farmers to Urban Society in the Ancient Near East
critiques theories up to the late 1970s
Ancient Civilizations
summarizes the world’s earliest states for beginning readers and includes some discussion of theories of the origins of states. A recent survey
The Emergence of Pre-Modern States: New Perspectives on the Development of Complex Societies
Bruce Trigger, Understanding Early Civilizations: A Comparative Study
is a definitive work for scholars. Important, more recent ­discussions of the origins of states: Richard Blanton with Lane F

container-title: See also excellent essays in Ronald K. Faulseit
Beyond Collapse
publisher: Center for Archaeological Investigations, Southern ­Illinois University Press
title: and Civilizations
On writing, Andrew Robinson’s The Story of Writing
is a lavishly illustrated essay for beginners. ­Collapse of civilizations: The best place to start is Joseph Tainter, The Collapse of Complex Societies
is somewhat dated, but is an excellent introduction before consulting more recent specialized sources

container-title: Nicholas Postgate’s Early ­Mesopotamia: ­Economy and Society at the Dawn of History
For the Hittites, see J. G. ­MacQueen, The ­Hittites
note: and ­Trevor Bryce, The Kingdom of the Hittites
title: Two books summarize the Sumerians admirably. Samuel Kramer’s The Sumerians
is a readable classic well deserving of its popularity. Harriett Crawford’s Sumer and the Sumerians
and the same author’s The Sumerian World ­(Abingdon: ­Routledge, 2016) are up-to-date accounts
is also definitive

container-title: J
note: L ­ esley ­Fitton, Minoans (Peoples of the Past) (London: British Museum Press, 2002); and Robert Castleden, Mycenaeans: Life in Bronze Age Greece (­London: Other, 2005).
title: Collapse of the Bronze Age: The Story of Greece, Troy, Israel, Egypt, and the Peoples of the Sea
The End of the Bronze Age
For the Minoans and ­Mycenaeans, see Oliver Dickinson, The Aegean Bronze Age
Ancient Egypt: State and Society
while Barry Kemp’s Ancient Egypt: The Anatomy of a Civilization

note: For Aksum, see David Phillipson, A­ ncient ­Ethiopia: Aksum, Its Antecedents and Successors (London: ­British Museum Press, 1998).
title: is an in-depth treatment. Nicholas Reeves’s The Complete Tutankhamun
is a magnificent tour of the golden pharaoh’s sepulcher. ­Nubia is little known to anyone but specialists, but David O’Connor’s A ­ ncient ­Nubia: Egypt’s Rival in Africa
offers an update. For Meroe and Kush, see Derek Aelsby, The Kingdom of Kush: The Napatan and Meroitic E­ mpires
Graham Connah’s African Civilizations
is a superb ­account of early African kingdoms, including Nubia, Meroe, and ­Aksum. ­Nehemiah Levetzion’s Ancient Ghana and Mali
The Zimbabwe Culture: Origins and Decline of Southern Zambezian States
provide beginning descriptions. François-Xavier Fauvelle, The Golden Rhinoceros
is a beautifully written account of societies that were in what he calls “The ­African Middle Ages

container-title: See also Li Liu, State Formation in Early China
also see Charles Higham and Rachanie Thosarat’s Prehistoric Thailand
which describes recent excavations. Charles Higham, The Civilization of Angkor
title: The Indus: Lost Civilizations
is an admirable summary of the Indus civilization and its mysterious script. See also Rita Wright, The Ancient Indus
Raymond Allchin’s The ­Archaeology of Historic South Asia
covers the Mauryan and later societies. Li Liu and X ­ ingcan Chen, The Archaeology of China
is an up-to-date, comprehensive synthesis
For Southeast Asia generally, see Charles Higham, Early Cultures of Mainland ­Southeast Asia
is an excellent summary of this important state

note: For Maya script, see Michael Coe, Breaking the Maya Code,
title: is the classic description of this flamboyant civilization

container-title: Jeremy A. Sabloff’s The Cities of Ancient Mexico
David Webster, The Fall of the Ancient Maya
note: is an excellent account of the collapse.
title: Linda Schele and David F ­ reidel’s A Forest of Kings
is a popular synthesis of Maya history based on both archaeology and glyphs, which is seminal, if controversial in places. Their Maya Cosmos
discusses Maya astronomy and world views
provides a guide to major Mesoamerican sites

container-title: and in Esther Pasztory, Teotihuacán: An Experiment in Living
Richard Diehl summarizes the Toltecs in Tula, the Toltec Capital of Ancient Mexico
note: For the Aztecs, see Geoffrey W. Conrad and Arthur A. Demarest, Religion and Empire (Cambridge, England: Cambridge University Press, 1984). Their civilization is described in Michael Smith, The Aztecs (The Peoples of America),
title: Ancient Mexico and Central America
is an excellent synthesis. Kent ­Flannery’s edited The Early Mesoamerican Village
contains valuable information on early complexity in the Valley of Oaxaca. Joyce Marcus and Kent Flannery’s The Zapotec Civilization
is a richly illustrated account of Monte Albán and the origins of civilization in the Valley of Oaxaca. Teotihuacán is well described in René
Drewitt, and George Cowgill’s Urbanization at Teotihuacán
William Saunders, Jeffrey Parsons, and Robert Santley’s The Basin of Mexico
describes the comprehensive archaeological surveys carried out in this highland region

container-title: Tiwanaku: see Alan Kolata, Tiwanaku
note: Chan Chan: Andean Desert City ­(Albuquerque: University of New Mexico Press, 1982). The Inca: Both Terence N. D’Altroy, The Incas,
and Craig Morris and Adriana von Hagen, The Incas (London: Thames and ­Hudson, 2012) are excellent accounts.
title: Further Reading Michael Moseley’s The Incas and Their Ancestors
is an excellent summary of Andean archaeology for the general reader. Jerry Moore, A Prehistory of South America
is informative and readable. Lawrence Sullivan’s monumental excursion into traditional Latin American religions, Icanchu’s Drum
is essential for any student of Andean archaeology. The Moche: Jeffrey Quilter, The Moche of Ancient Peru

Christopher Donnan and Walter Alva’s Royal Tombs of Sipán (Los Angeles: Fowler Museum of Cultural History, UCLA, 1994) is the definitive account of one of the most spectacular archaeological finds of the twentieth century
For Chimu
A General History of the Things of New Spain
Lost City of the Incas
Dawn of Art: The Chauvet Cave
The Conquest of New Spain
Zuni
Return to Babylon
Humans before Humanity
Killing Civilization: A Reassessment of Early Urbanism and Its Consequences
History Begins at Sumer
Laetoli: A Pliocene Site in Northern Tanzania
Aztec Thought and Culture: A Study of the Ancient Nahuatl Mind
Ancient Egyptian Literature: A Book of Readings
A Forest of Kings
Incidents of Travel in Chiapas and Yucatan
Icanchu’s Drum

title: Teeth, Needles, Dogs, and Siberian Bioarchaeo-­ logical Evidence for the Colonization of the New World
The Indus Civilization
The Evolution of Culture
